questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with frequent heartburn. A biopsy of the esophageal mucosa is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the stain used in this case?

choices.text: It stains foamy macrophages in Whipple's disease
It does not stain mucin of gastric mucosa
It can demonstrate hemosiderin and iron
It stains calcified tissues in malakoplakia

questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms and histology findings are suggestive of Barrett's esophagus, and mucin stain (Alcian blue) is used to identify goblet cells, which are indicative of the intestinal metaplasia occurring in the condition. It does not stain mucin of the gastric mucosa. It is a positive stain for acidic mucins of the intestinal mucosa and a negative stain for neutral mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland.

Barrett's esophagus is a type of metaplasia at the gastro-esophagal junction due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The squamous esophageal mucosa is converted to a columnar/intestinal type that is better suited to handle acid reflux. It is associated with an increased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

Grossly it appears as tongues of red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction. This metaplastic mucosa alternates with residual smooth, pale squamous (esophageal) mucosa. Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett's esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.

Option A: The foamy macrophages in Whipple's disease stain positive with periodic acid–Schiff (PAS).

Option C: Hemosiderin and iron is demonstrated by Perl's Prussian blue stain. It is used in hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, which shows hepatocellular iron. Iron is stained blue with this stain.

Option D: Von Kossa stain demonstrating calcium and iron-containing Michaelis-Gutman bodies (MG bodies) in malakoplakia is shown in the image given below:

questions.text: The micrograph of a section of a diseased liver, stained with Masson’s Trichrome stain,  is given below.  The arrow points to:
questions.solution:
The arrow in the above micrograph of the diseased liver points to areas of fibrosis containing collagen that is stained blue by Masson’s trichrome stain. 

The liver has a prominent (centrilobular) macrovesicular steatosis (white/clear round/oval spaces) and mild fibrosis (blue). The hepatocytes are stained red.

The differential diagnoses of centrilobular macrovesicular hepatic steatosis are:

  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Alcohol

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with complaints of pigmentation on her face. An excisional biopsy was done, and histopathology findings are shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pigmentation in the face and histopathology showing dense intracytoplasmic brownish-black melanin pigment are suggestive of malignant melanoma. 

Malignant melanoma primarily arises from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction.

The lesions of melanoma can be described using the ABCDE criteria. It comprises Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variegation, Diameter of more than 6 mm and Evolution or change

The image below shows a case of malignant melanoma.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of melanoma is histopathological examination. Markers for melanoma are S100, Melan-A, and HMB-45.

Breslow's index is used to measure the depth of invasion, which helps in determining the prognosis.

Related Pearl: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

questions.text: A young boy who is a known case of Klinefelter's syndrome presents with a painless scrotal swelling and precocious puberty. After an initial ultrasound that revealed a testicular mass, surgical removal was done. The specimen was sent for histopathological analysis; the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the biopsy findings points towards the diagnosis of a Leydig cell tumor.

Development of a painless testicular mass in a child with a history of Kleinfelter's syndrome and precocious puberty is suggestive of an androgen-secreting tumor like Leydig cell tumor. The biopsy shows large polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm. The cytoplasm also shows rod-shaped crystals referred to as "crystalloids of Reinke" which confirms the diagnosis.

Leydig cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They predominantly secrete androgens and in some cases estrogen and corticosteroids as well. The most common presenting features in prepubertal children are painless testicular swelling and precocious puberty. Leydig-cell tumors are associated with:

  • Kleinfelter's syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Hereditary leiomyomatosis
  • Renal cell carcinoma syndrome caused by germline mutations in the enzyme fumarate hydratase.

It appears as a homogenous golden-brown tumor, that is usually less than 5cm. On microscopy, round or polygonal cells with a round to oval nucleus and deeply acidophilic with granular cytoplasm are seen. In about 25% of the patients, the cytoplasm contains crystalloids of Reinke as shown below:


Other options:

Option B - Sertoli cell tumors are sex-cord stromal cell tumors of the testis. They are usually hormonally inactive and present only as a painless testicular mass. It is associated with Carneys complex, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, and familial adenomatosis polyposis syndrome. On microscopy, tumor cells are arranged in trabaculae to form cord-like structures and tubules as shown below:


Option C - Yolk-sac tumor is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor of the testis also known as endodermal sinus tumor. They secrete α-fetoprotein. On microscopy, a typical lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells, is seen. In half the cases, a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and parietal layer of cells is present known as Schiller-Duval bodies as shown below:


Option D - Seminoma testis is the most common germ cell tumor. They present as large bulky tumors, without any hemorrhage or necrosis. On microscopy, seminoma cells are round to polyhedral and have a distinct cell membrane, clear or watery-appearing cytoplasm, and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli as shown below:

questions.text: The image given below shows an H&E-stained section of a lung tumor. The immunohistochemical studies of this tumor are most likely to express which of the following tumor markers?
questions.solution:
The above H&E stained histopathological image of a lung tumor shows keratin pearls suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Cytokeratins are the tumor markers that are most likely to be expressed.

Cytokeratins are the intermediate filaments expressed by epithelial cells. The presence of cytokeratins on immunohistochemistry suggests a carcinoma of epithelial origin. Tumors of epithelial origin include squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma etc.

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is commonly seen in men and has an increased risk with smoking. The tumor appears like a cauliflower-like mass that is gray-white, firm to hard, and bulky with hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathological features include keratinization in the form of squamous pearls. The cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha-fetoprotein is a marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis. 

Option B: Calretinin serves as a marker for mesothelioma.

Option C: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a marker for colon carcinoma and other malignancies including the pancreas, stomach, and heart.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with congestive cardiac failure develops difficulty in breathing. A section of his lung tissue is shown below. What are the cells indicated in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows heart failure cells and the clinical scenario describes pulmonary edema due to heart failure. Heart failure cells are siderophages (hemosiderin-containing macrophages) seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema due to left heart failure.

The alveolar walls become thickened, fibrosed and contain these pigmented macrophages which produces brown induration of lung.

questions.text: The tumor cells as shown in the image are seen in:
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the slide are cloverleaf or flower cells with multilobulated nuclei that are frequently observed in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a neoplasm of CD4+ cells and is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.

Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.

Other options:

Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. 

Peripheral T cell lymphoma is composed of malignant T cells of varied sizes with infiltration of reactive cells, such as eosinophils and macrophages. 

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma occurs due to mutation in ALK gene. It consists of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and spacious cytoplasm (hallmark cells).

questions.text: Perl's Prussian blue staining of the bone marrow aspirate of a patient reveals the following. Which of the following is used in the treatment of his anemia?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a ringed sideroblast. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anaemia.

Pyridoxine 100 - 200 mg per day for 2-3 months is administered routinely to all cases of sideroblastic anaemia. Blood transfusion and other supportive therapy are also indicated. In cases of secondary sideroblastic anaemia, the primary focus is the removal of the offending agent. However, no definitive treatment is available for hereditary and idiopathic types of sideroblastic anaemia.

Sideroblasts are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue stain. Based on aetiology, sideroblastic anaemia is classified into hereditary and acquired types.

Hereditary sideroblastic anaemia is an X-linked disorder caused due to a defect in the activity of aminolevulinic acid (ALA) synthetase required for heme synthesis. Affected females act as carriers while males have moderate to marked anaemia and manifest in childhood or during early adulthood

Acquired sideroblastic anaemia:

I) Primary acquired:

  • Also called idiopathic or refractory acquired sideroblastic anaemia
  • Occurs in middle-aged and older individuals of both sexes
  • Due to the reduced activity of the enzyme ALA synthetase, there is disturbed growth and maturation of the erythroid precursors at the level of hematopoietic stem cell
  • Moderate to severe anaemia, which appears insidiously
  • Neutropenia and thrombocytopenia may also be seen
  • Regarded as a myelodysplastic disorder in the FAB classification and thus considered preleukaemic

II) Secondary acquired:

May appear secondary to 

  • Drugs, chemicals and toxins: Isoniazid, Cycloserine, Chloramphenicol, Cyclophosphamide, Alcohol, Lead, etc.,
  • Haematological disorders: myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera, acute leukaemia, myeloma, lymphoma and hemolytic anaemia.
  • Miscellaneous: Carcinoma, myxoedema, rheumatoid arthritis and SLE.

Laboratory findings:

  • Peripheral smear: Hypochromic, microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anaemia
  • Absolute values: MCV, MCH and MCHC are reduced except in acquired type, where MCV is raised.
  • Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with macronormoblastic erythropoiesis. Marrow iron stores are raised. Pathognomonic ring sideroblasts are present.
  • Serum ferritin: Raised
  • Serum iron: Raised
  • TIBC: Normal
  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis: Normal

questions.text: A patient presents with anemia, weight loss, and fever. A peripheral blood smear was done, and the findings are shown below. Which among the following will indicate a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (ALL). Among the given options, translocations t(9,22) and t(4;11) are indicators of a poor prognosis in ALL.

questions.text: The bodies shown in this image (highlighted) are seen in which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows Call exner bodies which are seen in Granulosa cell tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene is seen in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumors.

Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumors. It is used in monitoring patients being treated.

Other options -

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumor cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes. The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa. 

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Krukenberg tumor.

Option D : A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the dermatology clinic with complaints of reddish-pink nodules on her back. The mother is worried about it being a tumour. A sample is sent for histopathological examination and the findings are shown below. Which variant of melanocytic nevus does this child have?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathological findings showing large fusiform plump cells with blue-pink cytoplasm is highly suggestive of the Spitz nevus (spindle and epithelioid cell nevus) variant of melanocytic nevus.

Melanocytic nevi (moles) are common benign neoplasms caused by acquired activating mutations in components of the Ras signalling pathway.

Based on the location, it may be junctional nevi, intradermal nevi or compound nevi.

Melanocytic nevi are thought to progress through a series of morphologic changes over time. Superficial nevus cells are larger, tend to produce melanin, and grow in nests. Deeper nevus cells are smaller, produce little or no pigment, and appear as cords and single cells. At the deepest extent of the lesions, these cells often acquire fusiform contours and grow in fascicles resembling neural tissue (neurotization).

Melanocytic nevi with neurotization indicate normal maturation change and help in differentiating benign nevi from melanomas (which lacks such features)

This morphological change in nevus cells occurs due to progressive loss of tyrosinase activity and acquisition of cholinesterase activity in deeper “nervelike” nevus cells.

questions.text: The autopsy of a 1-year-old child who died of congestive cardiac failure revealed multiple tumors of the heart located in the ventricles. What is the characteristic histopathologic finding shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and histological slide showing spider cells are suggestive of cardiac rhabdomyoma.

Microscopically, cardiac rhabdomyomas are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Histologic processing of the sample usually removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands. These strands stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane. This gives an appearance that resembles a spider and is hence referred to as spider cells.

Rhabdomyomas are mostly seen in the first year of life. They are discovered when there is an obstruction to a valvular orifice or cardiac chamber. Approximately half the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations. The other 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis. They are usually multiple and appear in ventricles preferentially. They often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas and not true neoplasms.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.

Myxomas are the most common primary tumour of the adult heart. Unlike rhabdomyomas, they are usually single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells (Option A) embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells(Option B). Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

Kulchitsky cells (Option D) are neuroendocrine progenitor cells that lines the bronchial epithelium and give rise to small cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with breathlessness, facial flushing, dull aching abdominal pain, and diarrhea. CT abdomen shows a mass in the terminal ileum. The histological image of the resected specimen given below is positive for synaptophysin. What is the characteristic histopathological finding seen?
questions.solution:
The given history and histological specimen positive for synaptophysin are suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. The characteristic histopathology finding is salt and pepper chromatin.

Carcinoid syndrome is a systemic disorder characterised by diarrhea, skin rashes, bronchospasm, tumors in the gastrointestinal tract, flushing and cyanosis. In some cases, the tumors can be present as cardiac lesions or bronchial tumor. The pathogenesis is mediated by components like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), bradykinin, tachykinin, histamine and prostaglandins. Ki67 index is used to analyse the prognosis of the condition. The tumors arise from Kulchitsky cells. Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum.

Histology of carcinoids typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules.

Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:

  • Neuron-specific enolase
  • Synaptophysin
  • Chromogranin A

Other options:

Option A: Squamous cell carcinoma is characterized by the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges.

Option B: Adenocarcinoma shows a lepidic pattern of spread with tumor cells crawling along the normal-appearing alveolar septa.

Option D: GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy comes to the clinic with pain and swelling in his right chest for 2 months. The pain progressively worsens day by day and it is worse at night and disturbs his sleep. Further examination reveals a mass that is biopsied and shown below. Mutations in CDKN2A are present in this patient. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of chondrosarcoma. The histopathological image shown has sheets of malignant chondrocytes that have abundant cytoplasm with the intralesional bone formation which is characteristic of the clear cell subtype of this bone tumor

Chondrosarcoma are malignant tumors that produce cartilage. They are subclassified histologically as conventional (hyaline cartilage producing), clear cell, dedifferentiated, and mesenchymal variants.

Conventional central tumors constitute 90% of chondrosarcoma. Individuals with chondrosarcoma are usually in their 40s or older. The clear cell and especially the mesenchymal variants occur in younger patients, in their teens or 20s.

Chondrosarcomas commonly arise in the axial skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. A slow-growing, low-grade tumor causes reactive thickening of the cortex but a more aggressive neoplasm destroys the cortex and forms a soft tissue mass. About 15% of these tumors are secondary, arising from preexisting enchondromas and osteosarcoma.

Chondrosarcomas arising in multiple osteochondroma syndromes carry mutations in the EXT genes and sporadic cases have mutations in IDH1 and IDH2. Silencing of the CDKN2A tumor suppressor gene is seen in these cases.

Histopathology:

  • They are large bulky tumors made up of nodules of glistening gray-white, translucent cartilage. The matrix is often gelatinous or myxoid. Spotty calcifications are present and central necrosis may create cystic spaces.
  • The cartilage infiltrates the marrow space and surrounds pre-existing bony trabeculae. The tumors have three grades based on cellularity, cytological atypia, and the mitotic activity
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma has sheets of large, malignant chondrocytes that have clear cytoplasm, numerous osteoclast-type giant cells, and intralesional reactive bone formation.
  • Mesenchymal chondrosarcoma is composed of islands of well-differentiated hyaline cartilage surrounded by small cells that mimic Ewing's sarcoma.

The image below shows the histopathology of chondrosarcoma with the red arrow showing the large malignant cells with prominent nuclei and the black arrow pointing to the intralesional bone formation.

Other options:

Option A- Osteoclastoma is characterized by giant cells (osteoclasts) and expresses RANKL. They have sheets of uniform mononuclear cells and giant cells. It is usually seen in individuals between 20 to 40 years of age. They mainly arise from the epiphysis but may extend to metaphysics. The majority of them arise from the distal femur and proximal tibia. 

The below image shows sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast type giant cells.

Option C- Enchondromas are the most common intraosseous cartilage tumor. These tumors generally have IDH1 and IDH2 mutations. They are usually seen in individuals between the ages of 20 to 50 years. They are predominantly seen as solitary metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones in hands and feet. They are well-circumscribed and contain cytomorphologically benign chondrocytes. Enchondroma op large bones are asymptomatic and are detected incidentally. 

The below image shows the cells of the gray-blue transplant suggestive of enchondroma. 

Option D- Ewing's tumor is a malignant bone tumor characterized by primitive round cells without differentiation. Most lesions contain a translocation 11: 22. It is the second most common tumor in children. They are predominantly seen in boys younger than 20 years of age. They mainly arise in the diaphysis of long bones, like the femur and flat bones of the pelvis. The cells are uniform and round with scant cytoplasm. Homer-Wright rosettes with a grouping of cells and a central fibrillary core may be present. 

The below image shows sheets of small round cells with a small amount of clear cytoplasm suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.

questions.text: A patient presented with a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint. There are no skin changes or neurological involvement. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei as shown in the image below. Which of the following is seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painless, well-circumscribed swelling near the wrist joint along with the nuclear-free zones between nuclear palisading observed in the given image is suggestive of schwannoma. Verocay bodies are seen in this condition.

Schwannomas are benign tumors that may arise directly from peripheral nerves and exhibit Schwann cell differentiation. They are commonly associated with mutations in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22. This results in the loss of expression of Merlin, the NF2 gene product. 

Schwannomas are simple to excise surgically as they are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are loosely attached to the associated nerve but do not invade it. Grossly, they appear as firm gray masses. 

Microscopically, it consists of dense areas called Antoni A area, and loose areas called Antoni B area.

  • The dense eosinophilic Antoni A areas contain spindle cells that are arranged into cellular intersecting fascicles. Palisading of nuclei is seen, with the nuclear-free zones between them, called Verocay bodies.
  • The Antoni B areas contain spindle-shaped cells that are loosely arranged and separated by a prominent myxoid extracellular matrix.

The symptoms associated with schwannoma arise due to local compression of the involved nerve or adjacent structures. Surgical removal is curative. If incompletely excised, the schwannomas can recur locally, but a malignant transformation is extremely rare. 

Other options:

Option B: Ferruginous bodies are seen in asbestosis. These are other inorganic particles that are covered by iron-containing substances. This iron is thought to be derived from ferritin within macrophages.

Option C: Miyagawa bodies are elementary, intracytoplasmic microcolonies of Chlamydia trachomatis found in lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option D: Councilman bodies are seen in liver cell damage which consists of hepatic cell degeneration and necrosis, ballooning of cells, and acidophilic degeneration of hepatocytes.

questions.text: A man presented with fatigue and a mass in the left upper abdomen. On examination, there was massive splenomegaly with no lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. His peripheral blood smear is given below. Immunohistochemistry revealed tumor cells to be positive for annexin A1, CD22, CD25, and CD103. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image shows hairy cells i.e. abnormal B cells having round nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like extensions. So the likely diagnosis is hairy cell leukemia. 

Hairy cell leukaemia is a rare type of B-cell tumour involving small lymphocytes. The specific activating point mutation is in the serine/ threonine kinase BRAFV600E.

Symptoms occur due to infiltration of bone marrow, liver and spleen. Clinical features include:

  • Massive splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Lymphadenopathy is rare
  • Pancytopenia - due to marrow involvement can also be seen
  • Monocytopenia - leads to increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections

Routine peripheral smear shows hairy cells (abnormal B cells) having round, oblong or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like extensions as shown below. 

Hairy cell leukaemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance. 

The pattern of bone marrow involvement on biopsy specimens is pathognomonic for hairy cell leukemia.

  • Diffuse infiltration of tumor cells with honeycomb appearance
  • Individual cells have a fried egg appearance i.e. the nucleus of each hairy cell is surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm
  • Dry tap is obtained upon performing bone marrow aspiration due to marrow fibrosis and the interlocking cell borders of hairy cells

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus ("fried egg"-like appearance).

Tests for hairy cell leukemia include:

  • CD11c, CD25 and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers
  • Pan-B markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22 also test positive 
  • Annexin A1 on bone marrow specimens have been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B cell malignancies.
  • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) stain is an important tool in the clinical diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia and yields positive results in  majority of the cases.

Management of hairy cell leukemia include:

  • Splenectomy
  • Cladribine (first line agent) and deoxycoformycin are highly active nucleoside agents that cause durable remissions in patients.

Other options:

Option A: Primary myelofibrosis is the replacement of the marrow by fibrous tissue leading to reduced bone marrow haematopoiesis. This results in cytopenia, and extramedullary haematopoiesis (in the spleen mainly). The peripheral blood smear shows tear drop-shaped red cells (dacrocytes).

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell tumor. Patients present with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities. Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138, syndecan-1 (adhesion molecule), and CD56. Bone-marrow biopsy shows mott cells (a variant of plasma cell) with globular inclusions called Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) or Dutcher bodies (if nuclear).

Option D: Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1, CD19, and CD20. The tumor is usually CD5+ and CD23−. Painless lymphadenopathy is the most common presentation. Other organs involved are spleen and gut.

questions.text: An autopsy was done on a patient who died from a neurodegenerative disease. The pathological specimen from his brain is shown below. What does the structure marked in the image comprise?
questions.solution:
The given image is a histological sample showing neurons with a Lewy body. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies that stain positive with periodic acid-Schiff. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease.

Other options:

Option A: Tau protein is seen in Alzheimer’s disease and the below image shows neurofibrillary tangles inside the neuron.

Option B: Amyloid plaques are made of beta-amyloid precursor protein (APP). They are deposited around the neurons. Amyloid plaque is shown in the image below:

 
Option D: Prion proteins deposit in the neurons and cause apoptosis. The degeneration of these neurons leads to spongiform encephalopathy. The protein gets deposited as plaques. The image given below shows the spongiform appearance of the brain seen in prion disease.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented to the OPD with an asymmetrical nevus with irregular margins and variegated colour on her arm. Recently, the nevus had become pruritic. The histopathological examination of the lesion is shown below. Which stain would have been used on the biopsy specimen in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest a diagnosis of melanocytic nevus. In the histopathological examination, the Masson Fontana stain is used which is used for detecting melanin (seen as a dark or black pigmented area) as shown in the above image.

Stains used for melanin:

Masson Fontana silver stain: The ammoniacal silver stains melanin black. It is also used to stain argentaffin granules, which are normally present in endocrine cells in duodenal mucosa and pathologically seen in carcinoid syndromes.

Melanin:

  • In general, melanin is considered as the only endogenous brown-black pigment present in the hair, skin, retina, iris, and certain parts of the central nervous system (as neuromelanin). Pathologically, it may be found in skin tumors like melanomas.
  • However, another black-colored endogenous pigment called homogentisic acid may be seen in alkaptonuria, where the pigment is deposited in the skin, connective tissue, and cartilage; this pigmentation is known as ochronosis.

DOPA-oxidase method: It is the most specific method for staining melanin. The stain works on the principle that the DOPA substrate is acted upon by DOPA-oxidase in the melanin-producing cells which produce a brownish-black deposit. 

Schmorl’s method: Stains melanin blue-green.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, pain, and swelling over the right thigh. On examination, a mass was noted over the diaphysis of the femur. Cytogenetic analysis showed translocation (11:22). The histopathology image is given below. Identify the most likely X-ray feature of this condition:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the histopathology image showing sheaths of small round cells that are PAS-positive are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma. Onion peel appearance is the most likely X-ray feature of this condition.

Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant tumor that occurs mainly in the age group between 10-20 years. The most common site is the diaphysis of long bones. Karyotyping shows a translocation (11:22). 

The gross specimen shows a tumor involving the whole medullary cavity. The bone gets expanded, the periosteum gets elevated and subperiosteal new bone formation occurs in layers.

Microscopically, solid sheaths of small round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm are seen. The cells show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors. 

The clinical features include persistent pain, swelling over the area and fever. On X-ray, a lytic lesion in the medullary area on the diaphysis of long bones will be seen. It also shows cortical destruction along with new bone formation. This is called onion peel appearance. 

It is a highly radiosensitive tumor. Radiotherapy for control of local tumor and chemotherapy with vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and adriamycin is considered.

Other options: 

Option A: Sunray appearance is seen in osteosarcoma. It occurs predominantly in the age group of 15- 25 years. The common sites are the metaphysis of the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia.

Option C: Soap bubble appearance is seen in osteoclastoma. It occurs predominantly in the age group of 20-40 years. The common sites are epiphysis of the lower end of the femur, the upper end of the tibia, lower end of the radius.

Option D: Mottled calcification is seen in chondrosarcoma.it occurs predominantly in the age group of 30 - 60 years. The common sites are anywhere in the flat bones and upper end of the femur.

  • Giant cell tumor in children

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presented with complaints of swelling and pain in the left ankle and knee and fever for 3 days. He had a history of sore throat 3 weeks ago. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral regurgitation. Histopathological findings are given below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Small or medium-sized vegetations on either or both sides of the valve leaflets are seen
Condition can occur after group A streptococcal pharyngitis
Subendocardial irregular thickenings are called MacCallum plaques
Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the lesion in the heart

questions.solution:
The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is acute rheumatic fever. The rheumatic fever phase of rheumatic heart disease is marked by small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

Rheumatic fever is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease that classically occurs a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. (Option B) Acute rheumatic carditis is a common manifestation of active rheumatic fever. It may progress over time to chronic rheumatic heart disease.

Aschoff's bodies are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells, and occasional plasma cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon.

Inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cord. (Option D) Over these necrotic areas, small vegetations called verrucae develop along the lines of closure. Irregular thickenings present in the subendocardium are called MacCallum plaques. (Option C)

Some major manifestations of rheumatic fever are:

  • Migratory polyarthritis of the large joints 
  • Pancarditis (myocarditis, pericarditis, or endocarditis)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (typically on extensor surfaces of extremities)
  • Erythema marginatum, an irregular circinate skin rash 
  • Sydenham chorea, a neurologic disorder with involuntary rapid movements

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve leaflet is thickened, with commissural fusion and shortening. There is thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. This can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice, leading to a fish-mouth appearance (buttonhole).

Image showing button hole appearance is seen in mitral stenosis in case of rheumatic heart disease.

Image showing Aschoff bodies seen in RHD.

Note: Small or medium-sized vegetations on either or both sides of the valve leaflets are seen in Libman-Sacks endocarditis. (option A)
